<ce:figure id="FIG1">
<ce:label>Fig. 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">An ORTEP drawing showing the coordination geometry of the copper metal center. Ellipsoids are scaled to enclose 20% of the electron density.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>

</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 1

An ORTEP drawing showing the coordination geometry of the copper metal center. Ellipsoids are scaled to enclose 20% of the electron density.

elements.content:
<ce:figure id="FIG2">
<ce:label>Fig. 2</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">A helical chain with <ce:italic>P</ce:italic> configuration formed by the bidentate nicotinate groups and Cu centers running along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic> axis (top), Chiral channel formed by the helical chain running along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic> axis (middle) and the polymeric structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> (bottom).</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr2"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 2

A helical chain with P configuration formed by the bidentate nicotinate groups and Cu centers running along the a axis (top), Chiral channel formed by the helical chain running along the c axis (middle) and the polymeric structure of 1 (bottom).

<ce:figure id="FIG4">
<ce:label>Fig. 4</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">(a) The polymeric structure of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The solvent molecules which occupy the cavities are removed for clarity. (b) A diagram showing the interactions among the square grids of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text:
Fig. 4

(a) The polymeric structure of 2. The solvent molecules which occupy the cavities are removed for clarity. (b) A diagram showing the interactions among the square grids of 2.

elements.clean_text:
Table 1

Crystal data for complexes 1 and 2[^a]

| Compound | 1 | 2 |
|----------|---|---|
| Formula  | CuC13H14O6N2 | CoC12H10O5N2 |
| Formula weight | 357.80 | 321.15 |
| Crystal system | trigonal | monoclinic |
| Space group | P3221 | C2 |
| a (Å) | 9.0718(14) | 11.225(3) |
| b (Å) | 9.0718(14) | 10.786(3) |
| c (Å) | 16.891(2) | 6.8130(16) |
| α (°) | 90 | 90 |
| β (°) | 90 | 107.690(5) |
| γ (°) | 120 | 90 |
| V (Å^3) | 1203.9(3) | 785.9(3) |
| Z | 4 | 2 |
| D_calc (g/cm^3) | 1.947 | 1.357 |
| F(0 0 0) | 732 | 326 |
| Crystal size (mm) | 0.1 × 0.1 × 0.4 | 0.02 × 0.1 × 0.2 |
| μ (Mo Kα) (mm^-1) | 1.852 | 1.109 |
| Data collection instrument | Bruker AXS P4 | Siemens CCD |
| Radiation monochromated in incident beam (λ(Mo Kα)) (Å) | 0.71073 | 0.71073 |
| Range (2θ) for data collection (°) | 5.18⩽2θ⩽49.16 | 5.36⩽2θ⩽50.06 |
| Temperature (°C) | 22 | 22 |
| Limiting indices | −1⩽h⩽10, −10⩽k⩽1, −20⩽l⩽1 | −13⩽h⩽9, −12⩽k⩽3, −7⩽l⩽6 |
| Reflections collected | 2033 | 785 |
| Independent reflections [R_int] | 1408 [0.0479] | 671 [0.0259] |
| Refinement method | full-matrix least-squares on F^2 | full-matrix least-squares on F^2 |
| Data/restraints/parameters | 1408/0/110 | 671/1/96 |
| Quality-of-fit indicator[^c] | 1.106 | 1.310 |
| Final R indices [I>2σ(I)][^a][^b] | R1=0.0552, wR2=0.1490 | R1=0.0423, wR2=0.1342 |
| R indices (all data) | R1=0.0625, wR2=0.1550 | R1=0.0440, wR2=0.1354 |
| Largest differential peak and hole (e/Å^3) | 0.809 and −0.642 | 0.786 and −0.418 |

[^a]: R1=∑||Fo|-|Fc||/Σ|Fo|.
[^b]: wR2=[∑w(Fo^2-Fc^2)^2/∑w(Fo^2)^2]^1/2, w=1/[σ^2(Fo^2)+(ap)^2+(bp)], p=[max(Fo^2 or 0)+2(Fc^2)]/3, a=0.0995, b=0.7189, for 1; a=0.0765, b=1.7429, for 2.
[^c]: Quality-of-fit=[∑w(|Fo^2|-|Fc^2|)^2/N_observed-N_parameters]^1/2.

elements.clean_text:
The synthesis and structures of two new chiral coordination polymers, Cu(nic)2(H2O)·CH3OH (nic=nicotinate) (1), and Co(nic)2
·H2O (2), are reported. Single-crystal X-ray crystallography structure determinations show that complexes 1 and 2 crystallize in the chiral space groups P3221 and C2, respectively. Complex 1 exhibits open channels, while complex 2 shows planar molecular grids.

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">The syntheses and structural characterization of two new chiral coordination polymers, Cu(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (nic=nicotinate) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), and Co(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), which were prepared by reactions of nicotinic acid with CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, respectively, are reported. Single-crystal X-ray crystallography structure determinations show that complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> crystallize in the chiral space groups <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>3<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>21 and <ce:italic>C</ce:italic>2, respectively. The Cu(II) centers in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> adopt a slightly distorted square pyramidal geometry, while the Co(II) centers in <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibit a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The metal centers in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> coordinate to both the pyridyl and carboxylate groups to form 3-D and 2-D framework structures, respectively. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits open channels that are occupied by removable CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH molecules, while complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows planar molecular grids.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract
The syntheses and structural characterization of two new chiral coordination polymers, Cu(nic)2(H2O)·CH3OH (nic=nicotinate) (1), and Co(nic)2
·H2O (2), which were prepared by reactions of nicotinic acid with CuCl2
·2H2O and Co(NO3)2
·6H2O, respectively, are reported. Single-crystal X-ray crystallography structure determinations show that complexes 1 and 2 crystallize in the chiral space groups P3221 and C2, respectively. The Cu(II) centers in 1 adopt a slightly distorted square pyramidal geometry, while the Co(II) centers in 2 exhibit a distorted octahedral coordination geometry. The metal centers in 1 and 2 coordinate to both the pyridyl and carboxylate groups to form 3-D and 2-D framework structures, respectively. Complex 1 exhibits open channels that are occupied by removable CH3OH molecules, while complex 2 shows planar molecular grids.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Recently, great effort has been devoted to the self-assembly of organic and inorganic molecules in the solid state because it extends the range of new solids with desirable physical and chemical properties . The range and variety of self-assembled inorganic structures that can be constructed relies on suitable metal–ligand interactions and hydrogen bondings, and the various types of polymeric structures include 1-D, 2-D and 3-D network structures . Chiral coordination polymers containing nicotinate ligands , which display optical properties , were the subject of several studies during recent years. Despite some recent progress for the synthesis of chiral coordination polymers, the ability to predict and control the supramolecular assembly of these molecules remains an elusive goal, and much more work is required to understand the effects of the metal center and ligand on the patterns of the molecular structure in the solid state. During our investigation on the reactions of transition metal (II) complexes with nicotinic acid, we have obtained two chiral polymeric complexes which show 3-D and 2-D framework structures. The syntheses and crystal structures of Cu(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (nic=nicotinate) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), and Co(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), form the subject of this report.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction
Recently, great effort has been devoted to the self-assembly of organic and inorganic molecules in the solid state because it extends the range of new solids with desirable physical and chemical properties . The range and variety of self-assembled inorganic structures that can be constructed relies on suitable metal–ligand interactions and hydrogen bondings, and the various types of polymeric structures include 1-D, 2-D and 3-D network structures . Chiral coordination polymers containing nicotinate ligands , which display optical properties , were the subject of several studies during recent years. Despite some recent progress for the synthesis of chiral coordination polymers, the ability to predict and control the supramolecular assembly of these molecules remains an elusive goal, and much more work is required to understand the effects of the metal center and ligand on the patterns of the molecular structure in the solid state. During our investigation on the reactions of transition metal (II) complexes with nicotinic acid, we have obtained two chiral polymeric complexes which show 3-D and 2-D framework structures. The syntheses and crystal structures of Cu(nic)2(H2O)·CH3OH (nic=nicotinate) (1), and Co(nic)2
·H2O (2), form the subject of this report.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>General procedures</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All manipulations were carried out under dry, oxygen-free nitrogen by using Schlenk techniques, unless otherwise noted. Solvents were dried and deoxygenated by refluxing over the appropriate reagents before use. The visible absorption spectra were recorded on a Hitachi U-2000 spectrophotometer. IR spectra were obtained from a Jasco FT/IR-460 plus spectrometer. Elemental analyses were obtained from a PE 2400 series II CHNS/O analyzer.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental
General procedures
All manipulations were carried out under dry, oxygen-free nitrogen by using Schlenk techniques, unless otherwise noted. Solvents were dried and deoxygenated by refluxing over the appropriate reagents before use. The visible absorption spectra were recorded on a Hitachi U-2000 spectrophotometer. IR spectra were obtained from a Jasco FT/IR-460 plus spectrometer. Elemental analyses were obtained from a PE 2400 series II CHNS/O analyzer.

elements.clean_text:
Materials
The reagents CuCl2
·2H2O, Co(NO3)2
·6H2O and nicotinic acid were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. and used as received.
Preparation of the Cu(nic)2(H2O) (1)
CuCl2
·2H2O (0.43 g, 2.52 mmol) was added to a methanolic solution (25 ml) containing nicotinic acid (0.75 g, 6.09 mmol). The mixture was then heated to reflux for 6 h until some blue solid began to precipitate. The solid was filtered out, washed with diethylether (2×10 ml) and dried under vacuum to give a blue powder. Yield: 0.75 g (91%). UV–Vis (DMF): 438 nm (ε=1406.2 M−1
cm−1). Anal. Calc. for C13H14CuN2O6 (M
w=357.80), C, 44.24; H, 3.09; N, 8.60. Found: C, 43.75; H, 3.01; N, 9.08%. IR (KBr disk): 1636(m), 1560(s), 1543(s), 1508(w), 1457(m), 1384(s), 1307(w), 1191(m), 762(m), 683(m), 669(w), 651(m), 472(w). Dark blue crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained by slow diffusion of CH3OH into a DMF solution of 1.

<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.29 g, 1.0 mmol) was added to a CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> solution (20 ml) containing nicotinic acid (0.25 g, 2.0 mmol). The mixture was then refluxed for 48 h to afford a red solution and a red solid. The precipitate was filtered and washed with ether (3<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>10 ml) and then dried under reduced pressure to give a dark red solid. Yield: 0.28 g (92%). UV–Vis (DMF): 382 nm (<ce:italic>ε</ce:italic>=1045.8 M<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>). <ce:italic>Anal.</ce:italic> Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>CoN<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (<ce:italic>M</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">w</ce:inf>=303.14), C, 47.55; H, 2.66; N, 9.24. Found: C, 47.54; H, 3.03; N, 9.67%. IR (KBr disk): 1385(s), 1192(s), 1048(s), 828(m), 756(s), 698(m), 451(w). Red crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained by slow diffusion of ether into a MeOH/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O solution of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Co(nic)2 (2)
Co(NO3)2
·6H2O (0.29 g, 1.0 mmol) was added to a CH2Cl2 solution (20 ml) containing nicotinic acid (0.25 g, 2.0 mmol). The mixture was then refluxed for 48 h to afford a red solution and a red solid. The precipitate was filtered and washed with ether (3×10 ml) and then dried under reduced pressure to give a dark red solid. Yield: 0.28 g (92%). UV–Vis (DMF): 382 nm (ε=1045.8 M−1
cm−1). Anal. Calc. for C12H8CoN2O4 (M
w=303.14), C, 47.55; H, 2.66; N, 9.24. Found: C, 47.54; H, 3.03; N, 9.67%. IR (KBr disk): 1385(s), 1192(s), 1048(s), 828(m), 756(s), 698(m), 451(w). Red crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography were obtained by slow diffusion of ether into a MeOH/H2O solution of 2.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>X-ray crystallography</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The diffraction data for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were collected at 25 °C on Bruker AXS P4 and Siemens CCD diffractometers, respectively, which were equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo K<ce:inf loc="post">α</ce:inf> (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">α</ce:inf>=0.71073 Å) radiation. Data reduction was carried out by standard methods with the use of well-established computational procedures . The structure factors were obtained after Lorentz and polarization correction. The positions of some of the heavier atoms, including the copper atom, were located by the direct method. The remaining atoms were found in a series of alternating difference Fourier maps and least-square refinements . The CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH molecule was found to be disordered, and the occupancies for the carbon and the oxygen atoms were set to be 0.5. The final residuals of the final refinement were <ce:italic>R</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">1</ce:inf>=0.0552, <ce:italic>wR</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>=0.1490. The crystallographic procedures for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were similar to those for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. Basic information pertaining to crystal parameters and structure refinement is summarized in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="TBL1"></ce:float-anchor>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystallography
The diffraction data for complexes 1 and 2 were collected at 25 °C on Bruker AXS P4 and Siemens CCD diffractometers, respectively, which were equipped with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ
α=0.71073 Å) radiation. Data reduction was carried out by standard methods with the use of well-established computational procedures . The structure factors were obtained after Lorentz and polarization correction. The positions of some of the heavier atoms, including the copper atom, were located by the direct method. The remaining atoms were found in a series of alternating difference Fourier maps and least-square refinements . The CH3OH molecule was found to be disordered, and the occupancies for the carbon and the oxygen atoms were set to be 0.5. The final residuals of the final refinement were R
1=0.0552, wR
2=0.1490. The crystallographic procedures for 2 were similar to those for 1. Basic information pertaining to crystal parameters and structure refinement is summarized in 
.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Syntheses</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">The complex Cu(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O) (nic=nicotinate) (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), was prepared by reaction of CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O with nicotinic acid in refluxing methanol while the complex Co(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>), was prepared by reaction of Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O with nicotinic acid in refluxing CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Cl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>. Their structures have been determined by spectroscopic methods and by X-ray crystallography.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion
Syntheses
The complex Cu(nic)2(H2O) (nic=nicotinate) (1), was prepared by reaction of CuCl2
·2H2O with nicotinic acid in refluxing methanol while the complex Co(nic)2 (2), was prepared by reaction of Co(NO3)2
·6H2O with nicotinic acid in refluxing CH2Cl2. Their structures have been determined by spectroscopic methods and by X-ray crystallography.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A single crystal X-ray structural analysis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> reveals the formation of a complex of stoichiometry Cu(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH. Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> conforms to the chiral space group <ce:italic>P</ce:italic>3<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>21. 
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG1"></ce:float-anchor> shows the coordination geometry about the Cu metal center, which adopts a slightly distorted square pyramidal coordination geometry with the bond angles only slightly deviated from 90° or 180°. The Cu atom is bonded to two <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> pyridyl nitrogen atoms (Cu–N=2.032 (6) Å) and two <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> oxygen atoms of the monodentate carboxylate groups (Cu–O=1.964 (4) Å) in the equatorial plane. The dihedral angles of the two <ce:italic>trans</ce:italic> pyridyl rings that coordinated to the Cu atom through the nitrogen atoms is 83.0°, while that of the other set is 18.1°. The Cu atom is also bonded to one H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O ligand (Cu–O=2.332 (1) Å) in the axial position to complete the distorted-square-pyramidal coordination geometry. Noticeably, each bidentate nicotinate ligand links two Cu(II) metal centers, and all the ligands extend approximately along the <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>-axis to form an infinite helical chain (
<ce:float-anchor refid="FIG2"></ce:float-anchor>, top). The most striking feature of this complex is that the infinite helices form a two-dimensionally extended hexagonal array with open pores (9.1<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>×<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>11.3 Å) that accommodate the water molecules that are coordinated to the Cu(II) atoms and the non-coordinating methanol molecules. The open channels are further linked through the nicotinate groups to form a 3-D framework structure (, bottom). It is also seen from  that the water molecules are all pointing to the centers of the pores. This helical structure is in marked contrast to the one found in the complex [Cu(pzca)(Me<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>CO)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>](BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>) (pzca=2-pyrazinecarboxamide) where the cavities are occupied by the BF<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">−</ce:sup> anions . It is also noted that helical coordination polymers with large chiral cavities have been prepared by dissolving [Ni(acetate)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] and benzoic acid in MeOH and layering with a solution of 4,4<ce:sup loc="post">′</ce:sup>-bipyridine in MeOH .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structure of 1

A single crystal X-ray structural analysis of 1 reveals the formation of a complex of stoichiometry Cu(nic)2(H2O)·CH3OH. Complex 1 conforms to the chiral space group P3221. 
 shows the coordination geometry about the Cu metal center, which adopts a slightly distorted square pyramidal coordination geometry with the bond angles only slightly deviated from 90° or 180°. The Cu atom is bonded to two trans pyridyl nitrogen atoms (Cu–N=2.032 (6) Å) and two trans oxygen atoms of the monodentate carboxylate groups (Cu–O=1.964 (4) Å) in the equatorial plane. The dihedral angles of the two trans pyridyl rings that coordinated to the Cu atom through the nitrogen atoms is 83.0°, while that of the other set is 18.1°. The Cu atom is also bonded to one H2O ligand (Cu–O=2.332 (1) Å) in the axial position to complete the distorted-square-pyramidal coordination geometry. Noticeably, each bidentate nicotinate ligand links two Cu(II) metal centers, and all the ligands extend approximately along the c-axis to form an infinite helical chain (
, top). The most striking feature of this complex is that the infinite helices form a two-dimensionally extended hexagonal array with open pores (9.1×11.3 Å) that accommodate the water molecules that are coordinated to the Cu(II) atoms and the non-coordinating methanol molecules. The open channels are further linked through the nicotinate groups to form a 3-D framework structure (, bottom). It is also seen from  that the water molecules are all pointing to the centers of the pores. This helical structure is in marked contrast to the one found in the complex [Cu(pzca)(Me2CO)0.5](BF4) (pzca=2-pyrazinecarboxamide) where the cavities are occupied by the BF4
− anions . It is also noted that helical coordination polymers with large chiral cavities have been prepared by dissolving [Ni(acetate)2] and benzoic acid in MeOH and layering with a solution of 4,4′-bipyridine in MeOH .

</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">A single X-ray structural analysis of crystals of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, obtained by slow diffusion of ether into a MeOH solution of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, reveals the formation of a complex of stoichiometry Co(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>

Structure of 2

A single X-ray structural analysis of crystals of 2, obtained by slow diffusion of ether into a MeOH solution of 2, reveals the formation of a complex of stoichiometry Co(nic)2
·H2O. Complex 2 was solved in the chiral space group C2. 
 shows the coordination geometry about the Co metal center. The cobalt metal center, which resides on a crystallographic 2-fold axis, adopts a distorted octahedral coordination geometry with the bond angles significantly deviated from 90° or 180° (
), presumably due the chelation of the bidentate carboxylate groups to the Co metal center. The Co atom is bonded to two cis pyridyl nitrogen atoms (Co–N=2.075 (6) Å) and two cis bidentate carboxylate groups (Co–O=2.059 (6) and 2.291 (7) Å). The carboxylate groups are coordinated to the metal centers in unsymmetrical fashions. All the Co metal centers in complex 2 are chiral and have the same handedness Δ. Adjacent Co atoms are linked to each other through the pyridyl nitrogen atoms and the oxygen atoms of the bidentate carboxylate groups to form the two-dimensional square grid, 
. The complex shows void space with a Co–Co separation of 7.748 Å. The cavities are occupied by the solvent molecules and the squares are further linked through extensive C–H---O hydrogen bondings (H---O=2.523 Å; ∠C–H–O=130.5°), . The square grids in complex 2 are in contrast to those found in the chiral complex Zn(nicotinate)2 where the pyridine rings of the nicotinate groups intrude into the square cavities to result in interdigitation of the 2-D square networks .

<ce:para view="all">Complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> make interesting comparisons with the mononuclear complexes Cu(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and Co(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
 and the three-dimensional Cu(II) coordination polymer Cu(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
. The complexes Cu(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> and Co(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> were prepared by the reactions of CuCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and CoCl<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, respectively, with nicotinic acid in NaOH solution (pH=6) at 60 °C. The coordination spheres of these two mononuclear complexes are octahedral, with two pyridyl nitrogen atoms and two aqua oxygen atoms in the equatorial positions and two aqua oxygen atoms in the axial positions. The complex Cu(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> was synthesized by treating copper nitrate with nicotinic acid under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions, and the Cu(II) centers adopt a coordination geometry intermediate between square pyramidal and trigonal bipyramidal. The tridentate nicotinate groups (with bridging carboxylate) link doubly carboxylate bridged Cu(II) dimers into a pleated-sheet structure through the coordination of their pyridyl nitrogen atoms, while the bidentate nicotinate groups link adjacent Cu centers to form zigzag chains along the <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>-axis and thus cross-link the pleated sheets formed by the Cu centers and tridentate nicotinate groups to result in a complex 3-D framework structure . A complex of the same formula of Cu(nic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> has also been prepared by reacting Cu(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.12"></ce:hsp>2.5H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O with nicotinic acid in the mole ratio of 2:1 for three days at 170 °C under hydrothermal conditions .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Complexes 1 and 2 make interesting comparisons with the mononuclear complexes Cu(nic)2(H2O)4 and Co(nic)2(H2O)4
 and the three-dimensional Cu(II) coordination polymer Cu(nic)2
. The complexes Cu(nic)2(H2O)4 and Co(nic)2(H2O)4 were prepared by the reactions of CuCl2
·2H2O and CoCl2
·6H2O, respectively, with nicotinic acid in NaOH solution (pH=6) at 60 °C. The coordination spheres of these two mononuclear complexes are octahedral, with two pyridyl nitrogen atoms and two aqua oxygen atoms in the equatorial positions and two aqua oxygen atoms in the axial positions. The complex Cu(nic)2 was synthesized by treating copper nitrate with nicotinic acid under hydro(solvo)thermal conditions, and the Cu(II) centers adopt a coordination geometry intermediate between square pyramidal and trigonal bipyramidal. The tridentate nicotinate groups (with bridging carboxylate) link doubly carboxylate bridged Cu(II) dimers into a pleated-sheet structure through the coordination of their pyridyl nitrogen atoms, while the bidentate nicotinate groups link adjacent Cu centers to form zigzag chains along the a-axis and thus cross-link the pleated sheets formed by the Cu centers and tridentate nicotinate groups to result in a complex 3-D framework structure . A complex of the same formula of Cu(nic)2 has also been prepared by reacting Cu(NO3)2
·2.5H2O with nicotinic acid in the mole ratio of 2:1 for three days at 170 °C under hydrothermal conditions .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The two main factors that govern the structures of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and all the complexes mentioned above are the coordination of the H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules and the role of the metal centers in influencing the coordination geometry. It is clearly seen that changing the metal center and introducing the water molecule can drastically modify the structures of the coordination polymers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The two main factors that govern the structures of 1 and 2 and all the complexes mentioned above are the coordination of the H2O molecules and the role of the metal centers in influencing the coordination geometry. It is clearly seen that changing the metal center and introducing the water molecule can drastically modify the structures of the coordination polymers.

<ce:section-title>Thermal properties</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is very stable in air at ambient temperature and almost insoluble in common solvents such as water, alcohol, acetonitrile, chloroform, methanol and acetone. Complex <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is also stable in air at room temperature but soluble in methanol. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out to examine the thermal stability of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The samples were heated up in air at 1 atm pressure with the heating rate of 20 °C min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. The TGA curve shows that <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is stable up to 120 °C. A total weight loss of 16.3% occurred in the temperature range 120–230 °C, presumably due to the removal of the guest methanol molecules and the bonded H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules per formula unit (Calc. 16.4%), and a sharp weight loss occurred in the temperature range 230–320 °C, consistent with the removal of nicotinate ligands and decomposition of the framework. The TGA curve shows that <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is stable up to 100 °C. A total weight loss of 5.6% occurred in the temperature range 100–150 °C, corresponding to the removal of the guest H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O molecules per formula unit (Calc. 5.9%), and a sharp weight loss occurred in the temperature range 380–420 °C, consistent with the removal of nicotinate ligands and decomposition of the framework. Their <ce:italic>T</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">m</ce:inf> values have been measured by using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), and these are 107.2° and 134.9° for complexes <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, respectively.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal properties
Complex 1 is very stable in air at ambient temperature and almost insoluble in common solvents such as water, alcohol, acetonitrile, chloroform, methanol and acetone. Complex 2 is also stable in air at room temperature but soluble in methanol. Thermal gravimetric analyses (TGA) were carried out to examine the thermal stability of 1 and 2. The samples were heated up in air at 1 atm pressure with the heating rate of 20 °C min−1. The TGA curve shows that 1 is stable up to 120 °C. A total weight loss of 16.3% occurred in the temperature range 120–230 °C, presumably due to the removal of the guest methanol molecules and the bonded H2O molecules per formula unit (Calc. 16.4%), and a sharp weight loss occurred in the temperature range 230–320 °C, consistent with the removal of nicotinate ligands and decomposition of the framework. The TGA curve shows that 2 is stable up to 100 °C. A total weight loss of 5.6% occurred in the temperature range 100–150 °C, corresponding to the removal of the guest H2O molecules per formula unit (Calc. 5.9%), and a sharp weight loss occurred in the temperature range 380–420 °C, consistent with the removal of nicotinate ligands and decomposition of the framework. Their T
m values have been measured by using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), and these are 107.2° and 134.9° for complexes 1 and 2, respectively.
